ALLEGATION: Youth A was restrained incorrectly by Staff 1.
INVESTIGATION:
On 9/8/21, I spoke to Administrator 1 and reviewed the video. Administrator 1 reported
in the video Staff 1 went towards Youth A instead of away from Youth A to deescalate
the situation. This was observed by this Consultant as well.
3

I reviewed the following throughout the course of the investigation:
 Video recording
 Incident Report
I reviewed the video dated for 8/18/21 at 3:02:31pm.
3:02:36: Youth A is at back area in dorm near a table and throws papers off table
3:02:53: Youth A comes towards Staff 1 in aggressive manner and then paces
around
3:03:02: Youth A then walks towards Staff 1 and Staff 1 takes a step towards
Youth A. Both Youth A and Staff 1 are face to face with little space in between them.
Staff 2 is entering into unit and going towards Staff 1 and Youth A
3:03:04: Staff 1 grabs Youth A’s wrists, Staff 2 grabs Youth A’s left arm
3:03:16: Staff 1 grabs Youth A’s right arm and right shoulder and then Staff 1
wraps his left arm around Youth A’s neck in a “headlock” position
3:03:07: Both staff and Youth A fall to the ground
3:03:12 Staff 1 still ahs Youth A in a “headlock” position
3:03:15 Supervisor 1 comes into unit. Youth A is in prone position. Staff 1 is
holding Youth A’s right arm down; Staff 2 is holding Youth A’s legs down, and
Supervisor 1 is near the upper body holding unknown area
3:04:20: Supervisor 1 relieves Staff 1 and Supervisor 1 and Staff 2 are now
holding Youth A in prone position. Youth A is moving his head back and forth.
I reviewed the CPI (Crisis Prevention Manual). Prone restraints and headlocks are not
apart of CPI training.
I interviewed Staff 1. Staff 1 reported Youth A was cussing and not listening. Staff 1
reported he set limits with Youth A and told him to go to the back to the unit to calm
down. Staff 1 reported there were four or five other youth on the unit. Staff 1 reported he
continued to tell Youth A to stop swearing and to refocus. Youth A then threw items off
the table. Staff 1 reported he called a “Code 2” which meant he needed assistance.
Staff 1 reported Staff 2 came into the unit and removed the other youth. Staff 1 reported
Youth A began to walk back to the front area, making threats and “messing” with the
cubicles with items in them. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 came into the unit and Youth A
walked up on him (Staff 1). Staff 1 reported he did not move forward towards Youth A.
Staff 1 reported that he attempted to complete a two-man control position, grabbed
Youth A’s arm and then Youth A was able to get his arm loose, causing them to fall onto
the ground together. Staff 1 reported, while on the ground, Staff 1 and Staff 2 were able
to gain control of Youth A and then Supervisor 1 came into the unit and relieved him.
Staff 1 reported Youth A was in a prone position. Staff 1 reported Youth A never
vocalized being hurt or in any duress. Staff 1 reported he does not remember placing
Youth A in a “headlock” position, but did report that a “headlock” would not be a CPI
technique.
I interviewed Staff 2. Staff 2 reported Youth A became agitated because he did not get
his level. Staff 2 reported Youth A was using profanity and Staff 1 told him to stop. Staff
2 reported a “code 2” was called so he entered into the unit and removed the other
4

youth in the room. Staff 2 reported he saw papers on the floor by the table. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 had a calm demeanor. Staff 2 reported Youth A approached Staff 1 with
closed fist and threatened him. Staff 2 reported he attempted to talk to Youth A but he
would not listen. Youth A then bumped his chest into Staff 1 and then Staff 1 reported
he grabbed Youth A’s left wrist. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 grabbed his right wrist and they
attempted a two-man team control. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 lost his footing and they all
fell to the ground. Staff 2 reported he did not see what else might have happened with
Staff 1 and Youth A. Staff 2 reported Youth A was in prone position and that CPI does
not teach to perform prone restraints. Staff 2 reported he was unsure what to do if they
did get a youth into the prone position like they did. Staff 2 reported they kept him in
prone position. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 was attempting to help Youth A the whole time.
I interviewed Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1 reported she had come into the unit to help.
Staff 1 and Staff 2 were already on the ground with Youth A in a prone position.
Supervisor 1 could tell that Staff 1’s presence was escalating Youth A so she removed
him from the unit. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was able to move his head the whole
time and was talking to her. Supervisor 1 reported he was not in duress. Supervisor 1
reported if they do have someone in prone restraint, they are to turn the youth into the
right position. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A never reported to her that Staff 1 hurt him.
I reviewed the Incident report dated 8/18/21. Youth was seen by the nurse on 8/18/21.
No injuries were noted.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and
procedures regarding restraint. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
5

ANALYSIS: Video observation of the incident show Staff 1 stepping towards
Youth A, but not in a manner to start a two-man team control.
This move placed Youth A and Staff 1 face to face, chest to
chest. Staff 1 placed Youth A in a “headlock” position at one
point and Youth A was placed in a prone restraint. All staff
report they placed Youth A in a prone restraint. CPI manual
does not train to enter in youth’s personal space (unless
restraining) or to use a “headlock” position or prone position to
secure a youth in escalation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS: The Child Protection Law policy does not
designate a time to report other than immediately.
INVESTIGATION:
Administrator 1 reported this restraint happened on 8/18/21, but they didn’t call it into
centralized intake until 9/2/21 due to them unsure of whether they should call it in. After
discussing with Administrator 2, they decided this should be called into centralized
intake. Administrator 1 reported because there were not marks and bruises they were
unsure if it fit the threshold for suspected abuse and neglect.
Administrator 2 reported their policy stated they have to call suspected abuse and
neglect “immediately” and felt like they had done so when they discussed the event.
I reviewed the agencies’ current Compliance with Child Protection Law policy.
The policy was updated on February 8, 2016. The policy does not denote a
specific time frame the agency is to call centralized intake after having knowledge
of an incident where suspected abuse and neglect may have occurred.
I reviewed the Child Protection Law, Act 238 of PA 1975.
(1) An individual is required to report under this act as follows: (a) A physician,
dentist, physician's assistant, registered dental hygienist, medical examiner, nurse,
person licensed to provide emergency medical care, audiologist, psychologist, marriage
and family therapist, licensed professional counselor, social worker, licensed master's
social worker, licensed bachelor's social worker, registered social service technician,
social service technician, a person employed in a professional capacity in any office of
the friend of the court, school administrator, school counselor or teacher, law
enforcement officer, member of the clergy, or regulated child care provider who has
reasonable cause to suspect child abuse or child neglect shall make an immediate
report to centralized intake by telephone, or, if available, through the online reporting
system…
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
required.
The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure
compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL
722.621 to 722.638
ANALYSIS: The word “immediately” is not defined in the Child Protection
Law or in the agency’s policy. Although not defined in the law
and could be subjective in defining a specific time frame, the
word “immediately” denotes something happening without delay
or at once, or without lapse of time. The incident occurred on
8/18/21 and the agency contacted centralize intake on 9/2/21.
This lapse in time, is beyond “immediately”. The agency will
need to specify in their policy a time frame that will define
“immediately” so that there is no confusion in when an agency
must report suspected abuse and neglect.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
A. It is recommended that the agency’s license remain unchanged upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan.
